text: Hello. I have a team of 6 writers (who work remotely) and I would love to do monthly creative sessions or some sort of non-work meeting where we share ideas, writing hacks or maybe do a creative activity to expand our minds. Can you recommend a team writing/creative exercise that doesn't suck and that we can do virtually?  Thanks in advance for your amazing suggestions :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hello. I have a team of 6 writers (who work remotely) and I would love to do monthly creative sessions or some sort of non-work meeting where we share ideas, writing hacks or maybe do a creative activity to expand our minds. Can you recommend a team writing/creative exercise that doesn't suck and that we can do virtually?  Thanks in advance for your amazing suggestions

text:
I think you should first start with the goal of the meeting. Is it more of a team-building session? Are you trying to make your team better writers?

‚ÄúExpanding minds‚Äù sounds a bit vague and having no solid goal makes it difficult to get a positive result out of the exercise.

elements.text:
I think you should first start with the goal of the meeting. Is it more of a team-building session? Are you trying to make your team better writers?

‚ÄúExpanding minds‚Äù sounds a bit vague and having no solid goal makes it difficult to get a positive result out of the exercise.

text: Ironically, the group writing exercises that have really ‚Äúclicked‚Äù for me are group writing sessions where we just sit in a virtual room and write in silence for an hour. I LOVE that sense of shared productivity more than a creative exercise that doesn‚Äôt contribute to my current project.

elements.text: Ironically, the group writing exercises that have really ‚Äúclicked‚Äù for me are group writing sessions where we just sit in a virtual room and write in silence for an hour. I LOVE that sense of shared productivity more than a creative exercise that doesn‚Äôt contribute to my current project.

text: thanks <@U016BDEQ40J>. Good point. The goal is probably closer to "improving our writing skills with a team-bonding activity" It is meant to be fun and not feel like work. I know this could be a recipe for eye rolls, as most of these team-bonding activities fall flat. I am curious if there are activities that people have tried and enjoyed. Maybe even an interactive group course that is not too academic.

elements.text: thanks

. Good point. The goal is probably closer to "improving our writing skills with a team-bonding activity" It is meant to be fun and not feel like work. I know this could be a recipe for eye rolls, as most of these team-bonding activities fall flat. I am curious if there are activities that people have tried and enjoyed. Maybe even an interactive group course that is not too academic.

text:
Hi <@U01H58AMEAD>, we have a distributed team too, and we typically get together on a video call and have jamming sessions a la musicians. 

We do free-writing, writing prompts, and also picture prompts. We then read it aloud and exchange notes. 

I know this sounds pretty basic, but it's worked well for us. Oh, and we do this twice a month for about an 30-45 min. 

If you hit upon more interesting ideas, please share! If this works you, do let know how it worked and if it solved your problem. 

All the best! :raised_hands::skin-tone-4:

elements.text: Hi

, we have a distributed team too, and we typically get together on a video call and have jamming sessions a la musicians. 

We do free-writing, writing prompts, and also picture prompts. We then read it aloud and exchange notes. 

I know this sounds pretty basic, but it's worked well for us. Oh, and we do this twice a month for about an 30-45 min. 

If you hit upon more interesting ideas, please share! If this works you, do let know how it worked and if it solved your problem. 

All the best!

text:
Pinterest is a fantastic search engine within itself. Not only does Pinterest content rank on Google, but it is also just an amazing search engine that its users utilize to look things up, plus it has a feed based on interests that serves up amazing content.

As a millennial, I use Pinterest a ton, and I think that many people my age and younger/older utilize the platform.

Now, I have mainly used Pinterest as a lifestyle blogger. I get new users every single day from my Pinterest account. I am starting to dip my toes into using Pinterest for the B2B company I work for. With the right dedication, I feel like Pinterest can work for many avenues.

elements.text:
Pinterest is a fantastic search engine within itself. Not only does Pinterest content rank on Google, but it is also just an amazing search engine that its users utilize to look things up, plus it has a feed based on interests that serves up amazing content.

Now, I have mainly used Pinterest as a lifestyle blogger. I get new users every single day from my Pinterest account. I am starting to dip my toes into using Pinterest for the B2B company I work for. With the right dedication, I feel like Pinterest can work for many avenues.

text: Mm. I do these with my team sometimes. We just call them working sessions. Expectation is there's going to be something coming out of it, like an outline or a rough draft, that we can work on async or jam on together in another working session.

text: I would start with what element of the writing does it make the most sense to improve? If it's creativity, you could try a mad libs style exercise. If style, I've done one where everyone is given the same prompt, randomly assigned a writing style and then has to write on it. At the end, you all share and critique

elements.text: I would start with what element of the writing does it make the most sense to improve? If it's creativity, you could try a mad libs style exercise. text:
We're looking for an HR platform that specializes in managing independent contractors.

So far, we're looking at <http://Shortlist.net|Shortlist.net>, but their pricing is confusing.

Key features needed:

- Can handle a team of 200+ contractors
- Connects to job boards for quick publishing of new job ads
- Easy segmentation of worker profiles into various buckets (hired, don't hire, shortlisted, etc)
- Easy management of documentation - contracts and otherwise.

Any ideas?

- Connects to job boards for quick publishing of new job ads
- Easy segmentation of worker profiles into various buckets (hired, don't hire, shortlisted, etc)
- Easy management of documentation - contracts and otherwise.

Any ideas?

text: <@U01HEQWRG0G> Women ages 35-44 make up about 14% of Pinterest users and there are tons of users in the 25-34 range slightly under your ideal range that will likely grow to enjoy your products. I think you should definitely invest in the platform. It's worth creating a couple of boards and pinning some of your products and content. <https://blog.hootsuite.com/pinterest-statistics-for-business/>

text:
Hey everyone!
This is for folks who have published an infographic in the last 6 months or so....
We have a few in the pipeline and I'm looking for ways to promote and repurpose them (tips that work in today's context).
Also do infographic directories exist anymore?

elements.text:
Hey everyone!
This is for folks who have published an infographic in the last 6 months or so....
We have a few in the pipeline and I'm looking for ways to promote and repurpose them (tips that work in today's context).
Also do infographic directories exist anymore?

text:
Hey hey Taru - Love a good infographic! Including some ways we repurpose them below:
‚Ä¢ Blog post (highlighting the full infographic)
‚Ä¢ Social media series using snippets of the graphic
‚Ä¢ We also create a PDF version of the infographic that our sales team uses. They've found some good success by leveraging these assets, especially our BDRs
‚Ä¢ We also use them in our paid media display efforts (for retargeting) and boosted posts on LinkedIn
‚Ä¢ Email integration - typically we're just linking to the blog post, but it could be an interesting content piece to break down in a dedicate email (depending on the content itself) 
I haven't used an infographic directory in the past few years, but wouldn't doubt if you can still find some out there.

Are there any other use cases you were thinking of but are missing from my list? (always looking for ways to get more out of our content haha)

elements.text: Hey hey Taru - Love a good infographic! Including some ways we repurpose them below:
Blog post (highlighting the full infographic)
Social media series using snippets of the graphic
We also create a PDF version of the infographic that our sales team uses. They've found some good success by leveraging these assets, especially our BDRs
We also use them in our paid media display efforts (for retargeting) and boosted posts on LinkedIn
Email integration - typically we're just linking to the blog post, but it could be an interesting content piece to break down in a dedicate email (depending on the content itself)

I haven't used an infographic directory in the past few years, but wouldn't doubt if you can still find some out there.

Are there any other use cases you were thinking of but are missing from my list? (always looking for ways to get more out of our content haha)

text:
Hey <@U01L8LM4TU2> thank you so much!

This is super helpful. In the past we've also done a ton of PR (our product is B2B2C and the info is based on our own research, so that's practically meat for publications).
Another thing that has worked for us is repurposing it into videos.

I find your tips on paid media display and how your sales team uses it pretty interesting. Can you throw some more light on it? I'd love to explore these two as well.

elements.text: Hey

thank you so much!

This is super helpful. In the past we've also done a ton of PR (our product is B2B2C and the info is based on our own research, so that's practically meat for publications).
Another thing that has worked for us is repurposing it into videos.

I find your tips on paid media display and how your sales team uses it pretty interesting. Can you throw some more light on it? I'd love to explore these two as well.

text:
That is a great call out about proprietary research infographics and using that for PR. Do you have an examples of the video content as well? Are you able to keep that as a low lift effort? Love the idea of creating more multi media content out of these pieces.

And yes! We use quite a bit of industry research to help tell a compelling story and introduce our solution for a challenge or problem (ex: upskilling or DEI). The sales team is then able to use these infographics as a storytelling piece and attach it to their outreach messages.

It's helped improve open rates and replies for them. Of course the topics lend themselves well to that as well, but I think having a quick digestible piece versus a purely promotional asset and/or dense ebook helps with some of their prospecting.

elements.text:

It's helped improve open rates and replies for them. Of course the topics lend themselves well to that as well, but I think having a quick digestible piece versus a purely promotional asset and/or dense ebook helps with some of their prospecting.

text:
Our best performer is a video we made talking through the infographic. We embedded is within a blog post as well as uploading on youtube and promoting on all the usual social channels (plus reddit and quora etc).

The infographic has 11k views; the video is nearing 1k too.
